content:
my solution in ruby:
s=gets
if s.match?(/[a-zA-Z0-9]/)
puts'Syntax Error'else
o=s.gsub(/\|+/){_1.size.to_s}.gsub(/~/,?0)
puts o
p eval o
end

very fun clash

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Intriguing concept

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Le problème est sympatique

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very nice clash, solvable in Reverse and other modes. The Syntax Error rule is a bit hard to truly guess in Reverse mode, but the tests/validators are forgiving if you guess a simplified version of the rule (give error if digits or letters appear in input), so I think that works out well for Reverse.

This is a nice clash. I solved it in Reverse conditions just now without much trouble. The only possible issue is trying to reverse engineer what defines a Syntax Error... In my solution I just said if it contains a digit or letter then output Syntax Error and that worked out, but it's not really possible to confidently reverse engineer the exact rule from so few tests. ... I think it's probably ok though, since your tests and validators only introduce digits and letters for those cases anyway, so it doesn't matter if clashers guess the exact rule or not.

This is a cool EsoLang too, it was fun to decipher and play with it.

Before I can approve you'll have to erase the encode part from your solution sorry, but I highly recommend making a second clash for the encoding part. That looks fun. :)

This is my naive solution:

s = input()
if any([i.isdigit()or i.isalpha()for i in s]):
    print('Syntax Error')
    exit()
o=""
l=s[0]
x=1
for i in s[1:]:
    if i=="|":
        x+=1
    elif i=="~":
        if x!=0:
            o+=str(x)
        x=0
        o+="0"
    else:
        o+=str(x)
        x=0
        o+=i
if x!=0:
    o+=str(x)
print(o)
print(eval(o))


It took me about 8min to do, obviously this is bias since I made the clash xD.
It seems more simple this time, what do you guys think ?
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I think the problem is great, but making to give the answer to the problem in bars as the second line of output is a bit too much from this problem, I believe.

Encoding in it of itself is like a separate task, with decoding.
little bit to long
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Got it in 25 mins => that's too long for a clash

My Python solution:

from itertools import groupby
s = input()
d = {str(i): '|' * i for i in range(1, 10)} | {'0': '~', '.': '.', '-': '-'}
if any(i not in '|~.+-/' for i in s):
    print('Syntax Error')
else:
    s = s.replace('~', '0')
    l = [c * sum(1 for _ in g) for c, g in groupby(s)]
    l = ''.join([str(len(i)) if i[0] == '|' else i for i in l])
    print(l)
    f = eval(l)
    print(''.join(d[i] for i in str(int(f) if not f % 1 else f)))

It taked 30 minutes to me... No, this is really puzzle, not clash.

I just saw an issue with Bars.
How do you represent 11 ?
|| ->2
||||||||||| ->  92 or 11?

Your tests avoid numbers that have two contiguous non-zero digits!

I've been working on a Rust solution and it is harder than I expected.  Maybe I am just not good at Rust.  :-)

Tests should follow Test driven development (TDD) by starting with a subset of the most simplest feature first and then adding more functionality, and combinations, like this:

test 1:   |+|
test 2:    |||+||||
test 3:    ~+||
test 4     ||.|||+|.||
test 5     ~.|||+|

Get the idea?  Test one requires two lines of code to pass.  Test 2, just add a counter.  Test 3 recognize 0. Then decimal dot.

I still think it might be too complex for a clash.  I'm having to look up some parsing code.  I think cut the operations, or cut the fractions.  If one is good at parsing, doable, otherwise too difficult.

I would change all "programming language"  to "expression language".  
Since is not a whole language, but a way to express math expressions.

Your validators must be small variations on your test cases.  The point is to keep people from hardcoding their responses, not to trick then into missing a test case.  For example:

   test ||+~  
   validator |||+~

See how they both use plus and 0?  Only variation is off by one, the operation and recognition of special digit 0 is the same.

So go through each of your validators and make almost match each test with a boring variation.

I think this is a great challenge.  I think I would even simplify more by removing the zeros and decimals and just make them tally marks, but it is your puzzle!

Cases
* Please simplify the "Divisions" test and Validator 3 to operations between two numbers only. Each of them currently involve four numbers; while using eval to calculate the result is easy for players using the programming languages that support it, the need to deal with complex calculations would make it very time-consuming to write the code and unfair for other players.

Goal
* Please format "|" and "~" as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks.

Constraints
* Please mention that operations are restricted to additions, subtractions and divisions between 2 operands (after the cases have been simplified as mentioned above).

* Please mention that the results of all divisions have finite numbers of decimal places.

Thanks.
Thanks for the input, I made those changes.
I removed the fractions, as suggested.

nah you aren't getting it. As stated " numeric values are represented by their value in pipes". This means that to interpret a bars syntaxe number, you count the pipes, nothing more, nothing less. Thus 10 would not be |~ but ||||||||||
Does it make sense now ?
yeah, I'm working on shortening it, but I don't want to water it down too much so as not to loose the appeal of the clash.

Thank you for the advise, it's a great idea really!
I will change this for the next submission.
Yeah true, I will simplify in the future.
Thank you so much! Yeah I'll drop that method from the solution, thanks for the feedback!
thanks!

btw, how can I test it in reverse mode? I couldn't find the option when I click "test in IDE"

Also, do you have any advise as to how I could point out what makes a syntax error from within the tests ? I don't really want to end up writing it in plain text within them, seems a bit lame.

I think it's ok the way you've done it with the Syntax Error. It's hard to guess your exact rule, but you only really test that no digits or letters are in the input, which is easy to guess. So I don't think it will cause problems.

As for Reverse mode, there's no way to do it in the IDE, so I have some code I use where I copy+paste the tests/validators into it and it outputs JUST the tests, and comments them out so I can paste it into the IDE. Then in the IDE I resize things so I can't see the statement.

Thank you.

In Constraint section, would you please change "Floating point numbers must represented with no trailing zeros." to "The results of all divisions have finite numbers of decimal places"?

My wording means that players don't have to consider how many decimal places should be shown. For example, there won't be a case where the calculation required is 1/3 and the player won't know how many decimal places to show. It's got nothing to do trailing zeros.
yeah that's better wording thanks!
